pages.title: What is Bioinformatics?
content: Let's ask the creators of Jurassic Park!

pages.title: Recreating a DNA Strand
content: While this may have been true in 1993 when Jurassic Park hit theaters, today, many genomes have been sequenced.
In the following pages, we'll talk about why we would want to sequence DNA (besides creating dinosaurs) and how this is done.

pages.title: Page 3
content: First, let's take a quick quiz.  Which of these angry pigs is red?
Great!  Let's try a question that's a little bit harder.  Which of these two people has a genetic disease?
That's a little bit harder.  To figure this out, let's look at their DNA!

pages.title: Page 4
content: So...  How do we see their DNA?
to read the characters in their DNA.  Unfortunately, the DNA has to be chopped into a bunch of little pieces first.

pages.title: DNA reconstruction
content: Bioinformaticians have created tools that put these fragments in order
and put them into one big DNA strand.

pages.title: Slide 6
content: Now we can compare the DNA—look, there's a difference in this gene!
For less-obvious genetic differences, many tools are available to pull out the differences.

pages.title: Slide 7
content: Now that we see these genetic mutations, we can take preventative health care measures to help this girl with her inherited disease.
This is a helpful technique for finding people predisposed to certain types of cancer, for example.

pages.title: Slide 8
content: Genomes are really big!  Computers make finding genetic patterns and mutations fast and awesome.  Bioinformatics is great!
